summary: An email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney to a victim's attorney regarding the upcoming discovery production in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. It discusses the protective order, restrictions on disclosing victim identities, and seeks permission to inform defense counsel that the victim is represented to prevent direct contact.

persons.name: Assistant U.S. Attorney
persons.context: The author of the email, communicating with a victim's attorney about discovery procedures and protective measures in the Maxwell case.

events.title: Court Grants Protective Order in Maxwell Case
events.description: The judge ruled in favor of the government's motion for a protective order, prohibiting the defense from publicly identifying victims or witnesses referenced in discovery materials.

events.title: Planned Initial Discovery Production
events.description: The government plans to begin producing discovery materials to the defense in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, following the entry of the protective order.

keyFacts: A protective order was granted in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, strictly prohibiting the defense from publicly disclosing the identity of any victims or witnesses.
The government planned to begin producing discovery materials to the defense, which would include information about the email recipient's client (a victim).
The government sought permission from the victim's attorney to inform defense counsel that the victim was represented, to preempt attempts at direct contact.
The government noted its ability to produce materials was constrained by grand jury secrecy rules under Federal Rule of Criminal Procedure 6(e).
The defense had previously argued for the ability to publicly identify victims in certain circumstances, but the court ruled against them.
